headline.main: False Starts and Failures Thwart Quest for Safe Cigarette

docs.abstract: History of effort to produce less dangerous cigarettes discussed; industry stopped funding such research in early 1960's out of concern that work could spur flood of suits; Federal effort to develop safer cigarettes failed; consumers have shown little interest in such cigarettes; chronology of research efforts (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: When the Philip Morris Companies marketed a cigarette called Next in 1989, it never mentioned what a former company scientist says was an apparent advantage to the product: it had fewer cancer-causing compounds than a typical cigarette. The company's marketing of Next may well reflect the industry's historic ambivalence about developing a less-dangerous cigarette. For decades, the vision of a ''safe cigarette'' has loomed like a Holy Grail for anti-smoking advocates and industry researchers, but tobacco executives have long feared that they would lose customers if they acknowledged their product's dangers.
